image.altText: a man and woman sitting at a table looking at a photo of their daughter who died

items.synopsis: Queensland has been given the unfortunate title of the state or territory where you are most likely to have your car stolen.

title.children: Thieves took one of Janice's last links to her daughter — the car she drove before she died

image.altText: An orange sun sets over a city skyline, casting orange light across the horizon

items.synopsis: New data reveals how households that have been under interest rate pressure for more than 18 months are managing to make ends meet.

title.children: When something has to give, which bill payments do you miss? New NZ data has some clues

image.altText: King Charles and a smiling Anthony Albanese look at the camera as they shake hands

items.synopsis: The prime minister is putting aside his republican views to pledge allegiance to King Charles III to honour 'the system of government we have', but believes the day will come when Australia stands on its own two feet.

title.children: Albanese says 'it's not up to me' to refuse pledge of allegiance to King Charles

image.altText: a woman wearing a silk blouse speaks into media microphones outside a courthouse

items.synopsis: A Brisbane woman who was violently attacked by her partner with a hatchet has praised the "absolutely amazing" bystanders who helped her after the man responsible was convicted of her attempted murder.

title.children: Woman praises 'absolutely amazing' bystanders who helped her during violent hatchet attack

image.altText: NRL team mascots in the Brisbane CBD

items.synopsis: The city gets $30 million in kickbacks for tackling the logistical nightmare that is eight NRL games in three days at one stadium. Several states have approached the NRL for hosting rights.

title.children: Other states want it – so why is Brisbane fighting so hard to keep Magic Round in Queensland?

image.altText: A woman with a black spot on her nose

items.synopsis: When 42-year-old Nicolette Jane noticed a red, itchy lump on her nose, she went to straight to her GP, as a new study highlights the huge job doctors are undertaking to detect skin cancer.

title.children: GPs playing increasingly pivotal role in detecting skin cancer in Australians

image.altText: A lorry with a billboard of Julian Assange arrives at the front of a London court house.

items.synopsis: Giving his strongest comments on the case to date, Anthony Albanese tells the ABC he is 'frustrated' the US government is continuing its prosecution of Julian Assange despite being 'very aware' the prime minister opposes his ongoing incarceration.

title.children: 'It's frustrating': Albanese says he is disappointed the US has not been receptive to diplomatic solution on Julian Assange

image.altText: An older man is carried on a stretcher past a train by men wearing military helmets and vests.

items.synopsis: Moscow steps up strikes on Ukraine as Kyiv prepares for a counteroffensive in which it is expected to try to retake occupied territory in the Kherson region.

title.children: Russia says United States ordered Ukrainian 'drone strike' on Kremlin, as 23 die in Kherson

image.altText: A tight head shot of an Aboriginal woman with dyed blonde hair.

items.synopsis: Margaret Hawke will learn of her punishment today for the murder of her three children, just hours after seeking support, in a tragedy prompting calls for more mining revenue to be channelled back into the Port Hedland community.

title.children: As a mother awaits sentencing for killing her children, her town wants help to stop future tragedies

image.altText: People wearing warm clothes outside Sydney Opera House

items.synopsis: Polar winds will send temperatures diving this weekend, making for the coldest early May weather for three years across the southern and eastern states.

title.children: Weekend cold snap to see temperatures drop, snow, hail and thunder

image.altText: A baby sitting up, smiling, with a book in her hands.

items.synopsis: Prader-Willi Syndrome is experienced primarily as an insatiable and dangerous hunger. But parents and advocates say the reality of the condition is far more complex.

title.children: There's more to 'smiley' Evie's syndrome than an insatiable, life-threatening hunger

image.altText: a man with blood coming from his mouth after being hit

items.synopsis: Referee Khodr Yaghi suffered a broken jaw after being assaulted while officiating a match in Sydney's south last week.

title.children: Sydney soccer referees to wear body cameras after alleged assault at match

image.altText: A husband and wife overlook their garden while holding a wheelbarrow.

items.synopsis: Many Australian retirees are returning to the workforce these days. For some, it's out of necessity; for others, it's for more philosophical reasons.

title.children: Thousands of retired Australians are rejoining the workforce. Here's why

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: Australian shares are set to open lower in the wake of US markets falling on the back of growing concerns about the banking sector. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to drop, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

schema.headline: Live: ASX set to drop, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Wall Street drops on banking worries
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In the US, the benchmark S & P 500 declined 0.7 per cent to end the session at 4,061. It was its fourth-straight session of declines. The Nasdaq declined 0.5 per cent to 11,966, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.9 per cent to 33,127. The sell-off came as fears grew about the strength of the US banking sector. PacWest's stock slumped more than 40 per cent in afternoon trading, dropping to a record low. Western Alliance shares pared losses after plummeting by nearly 60 per cent following a Financial Times report that the lender was exploring strategic options, including a potential sale of all or part of its business. However, Western Alliance denied the report, calling it "categorically false in all respects", and said it was weighing legal options against the newspaper. The bank's stock was down nearly 35 per cent in afternoon trading. Western Alliance has been seeking to reassure investors about its financial stability. It comes as First Republic's collapse, the third major casualty of the biggest crisis to hit the US banking sector since 2008, rekindled a slide in shares of regional lenders this week despite regulatory efforts to staunch the turmoil that began with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March. US officials at the federal and state levels are assessing the possibility of "market manipulation" behind big moves in banking share prices in recent days, Reuters has reported. "Nobody knows where these banks should be trading at because what we saw with Silicon Valley Bank is that the fundamentals can change so quickly," Tom Plumb, portfolio manager at Plumb Balanced Fund said. "This normally would have been a great opportunity to buy banks with premier regional presence and it may be, but the real concern is nobody knows what the rules are and what they are valued at," Mr Plumb added. The KBW Regional Banking index dropped 3.3 per cent. Major U.S. banks were also losing ground on Thursday, with the S & P 500 Banks index falling nearly 3 per cent. JPMorgan's shares fell 1.4 per cent, while Bank of America declined 3 per cent. The common theme among the banking stocks that have sold off sharply is that they reported large deposit declines in the first quarter, said Truist Securities analyst Brandon King, while calling the selloff "overdone." PacWest Bancorp reported a loss of $1.1 billion attributed to shareholders for the first quarter of the year. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: It's Friday, and investors are getting worried about banks again
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Morning all. I'll be with you on the blog today. US stocks fell on fears about the banking sector. A California bank PacWest has been "assessing its options" including a possible sale. The ASX is set to drop at open. I'll have more financial news for you shortly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street drops on banking worries

children.content: P 500 declined 0.7 per cent to end the session at 4,061.
It was its fourth-straight session of declines.
The Nasdaq declined 0.5 per cent to 11,966, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.9 per cent to 33,127.
The sell-off came as fears grew about the strength of the US banking sector.
stock slumped more than 40 per cent in afternoon trading, dropping to a record low.

shares pared losses after plummeting by nearly 60 per cent following a Financial Times report that the lender was exploring strategic options, including a potential sale of all or part of its business.
Western Alliance denied the report, calling it "categorically false in all respects", and said it was weighing legal options against the newspaper.
The bank's stock was down nearly 35 per cent in afternoon trading.
Western Alliance has been seeking to reassure investors about its financial stability.

It comes as First Republic's collapse, the third major casualty of the biggest crisis to hit the US banking sector since 2008, rekindled a slide in shares of regional lenders this week despite regulatory efforts to staunch the turmoil that began with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March.
US officials at the federal and state levels are assessing the possibility of "market manipulation" behind big moves in banking share prices in recent days,

"Nobody knows where these banks should be trading at because what we saw with Silicon Valley Bank is that the fundamentals can change so quickly," Tom Plumb, portfolio manager at Plumb Balanced Fund said.

"This normally would have been a great opportunity to buy banks with premier regional presence and it may be, but the real concern is nobody knows what the rules are and what they are valued at," Mr Plumb added.
Major U.S. banks were also losing ground on Thursday, with the S
falling nearly 3 per cent. JPMorgan's shares fell 1.4 per cent, while Bank of America declined 3 per cent.

The common theme among the banking stocks that have sold off sharply is that they reported large deposit declines in the first quarter, said Truist Securities analyst Brandon King, while calling the selloff "overdone."
PacWest Bancorp reported a loss of $1.1 billion attributed to shareholders for the first quarter of the year.

image.altText: King Chalres and Albanese smile at each other as they shake hands in a lavish room of Buckingham Palace

items.synopsis: If, as speculated, the budget predicts a 2022-23 surplus, that further complicates the opposition's reaction. The Coalition is stymied, whether it attacks from the right or (less likely) the left, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Awkward questions for Albanese overseas as an intense tug of war builds at home

image.altText: Prime Minister Kalsakau and Penny Wong sign a security agreement

items.synopsis: Anxieties are growing in Canberra that a landmark security agreement between Australia and Vanuatu could stall in the Pacific nation's parliament.

title.children: Fears domestic Vanuatu politics could foil important security pact with Australia

image.altText: A man with a backwards cap stands in a pool and gives the peace sign to the camera

items.synopsis: The man who hit and killed a North Queensland road worker in a hit and run incident has been sentenced after hiding in a roof and attempting to escape police custody.

title.children: Magistrate calls hit and run culprit's attempts to flee police custody 'despicable'

image.altText: Katy Gallagher wearing a black jacket and purple top, looking to the right

items.synopsis: A series of parliamentary inquiries found the mutual obligations element of the program to be punitive and "akin to coercive control".

title.children: Federal government to abolish 'polarising' ParentsNext scheme

image.altText: Victorian power - Snowy Hydro

items.synopsis: A bitter rift between the former boss of state-owned power provider Snowy Hydro and federal Energy Minister Chris Bowen has widened following claims Labor's green energy plans are not achievable.

title.children: Fuse blown as former Snowy Hydro boss takes aim at 'bulls**t' renewable energy goals

image.altText: Aerial image of a series of lush green islands in a blue ocean. Clouds meet the horizon.

items.synopsis: Beautiful places and friendly faces have long been the selling point of Pacific tourism. But after the closure of international borders during the pandemic, environmental concerns are causing Pacific countries to resist a return to mass tourism.

title.children: Craving a Pacific Island getaway? Here's why locals are pushing for more sustainable travel

image.altText: A picture of Westmead Hospital in the western Sydney suburb of Parramatta

items.synopsis: It is unclear when cyber criminals managed to breach the Crown Princess Mary Cancer Centre, which is part of Westmead Hospital, but NSW Health officials said they were alerted to the threat late on Thursday afternoon.

title.children: Major cancer treatment centre in cyber attack, hackers demand $100,000 ransom for stolen data

image.altText: A police cordon and police car out the front of a suburban Darwin home

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Police say they are treating the death of Md Ishaqur Rahman Sifat, 23, as a homicide. A man remains in custody but has not been charged.

title.children: International student dies in Darwin hospital after violent home invasion

image.altText: Ms Lamb sits in a wheelchair and looks over her fence towards the camera.

items.synopsis: As talks about how to make the NDIS more sustainable ramp up again, people with disability say a good place to start would be with the costly and "exhausting" red tape.

title.children: Rayna needed a new wheelchair cushion but the paperwork alone cost her over $1,000

image.altText: Singer Ed Sheeran smiles while speaking to the media outside a Manhattan court.

items.synopsis: British pop superstar Ed Sheeran's 2014 hit Thinking Out Loud did not unlawfully copy Marvin Gaye's classic 1973 song Let's Get It On, a Manhattan jury decides.

title.children: US jury sides with Ed Sheeran in Let's Get It On copyright trial

image.altText: Penny Wong smiling, wearing a flower crown and lei over formal clothing

items.synopsis: A wide-ranging Pacific assistance package covering environmental, military, and economic support for Australia's closest neighbours will be unveiled in Tuesday's budget.

title.children: Australia to increase Pacific engagement with multi-million-dollar 'whole of government' budget package

image.altText: Terror-accused in custody being led onto a plane.

items.synopsis: The Supreme Court hears Ajazi travelled to Türkiye with his family in mid-2013, and then used that country as a base to "go back and forth" across the border into Syria from early 2014.

title.children: Queensland man intended to 'overthrow the Syrian government by force', court hears

image.altText: A man walking in a suit outside court

items.synopsis: Adam Cranston is one of five people found guilty of two charges over various roles in the Plutus Payroll scam, which ran for about three years to 2017.

title.children: Judge 'flabbergasted' legal aid pulled for one of architects of $105m tax fraud

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

items.synopsis: The nurses union warns the aged care sector has form when it comes to avoiding paying wage rises, and says the government must oblige providers to pass on a historic 15 per cent pay increase to all workers, not just those on award rates.

title.children: Nurses union fears nursing homes won't pass on 'historic' $11.3 billion budget commitment to boost aged care wages

image.altText: A man in a akubra style hat smiles at the camera while patting his white husky dog

items.synopsis: A neighbour who was with Sean Ferris minutes before he stabbed two police officers and was then shot dead says the incident should never has escalated to this — as homemade weapons and a Samurai sword are removed from the property.

title.children: 'It shouldn't have escalated to this': Man shot in police incident had known mental health issues, neighbour says

items.synopsis: The government is not collecting enough money, and you are paying too much, says the former Treasury boss.

title.children: The man who once held Australia's purse strings says the budget is a 'hell of a mess', but taxing you more isn't the answer

image.altText: A bird's eye view of the front seat of a car.

items.synopsis: Police allege the two boys stole a Mercedes-Benz that was later involved in a crash that killed three people.

title.children: Second 13-year-old charged over alleged car theft linked to triple fatal crash

image.altText: A drone photograph of a geothermal power plant in the desert.

items.synopsis: The $4-million plant was touted as the beginning of a renewable energy windfall for outback Queensland, but it never produced any power. Winton Shire Council is suing the project manager in the Supreme Court.

title.children: Failed geothermal power plant will cost $1.1m to fix, outback council claims
